newsitem.title: CHINA: China liquor output leads to local grain shortages.
newsitem.headline: China liquor output leads to local grain shortages.

text.p: China's northwestern province of Gansu is facing local grain shortages aggravated by rapid expansion of grain-based liquor production, the China Business Times said on Tuesday.

The province had some 70 liquor producers with annual capacity of more than 300,000 tonnes, the newspaper said, adding this was unsuitable for a grain-deficient province that still had about 4.0 million people living below the poverty line.
The newspaper did not say whether any measures were about to be imposed to restrict the use of grain for making liquor.
China has in the past said it might limit such use of grain or control the setting up of new production facilities for making grain-based liquor.
More than 10 million tonnes of grain are used nationwide each year to make grain-based spirits, the newspaper said.
About 70 percent of the grain used to make grain-based spirits in Gansu was shipped in from other provinces due to local grain shortages, the newspaper said.
China produced about 6.5 million tonnes of grain-based spiritis in 1996.

Average annual grain output in the province was 7.04 million tonnes in 1991-1994 while annual local consumption in the same period was 8.87 million tonnes, it said without giving more current statistics. --Beijing Newsroom (8610) 6532 1921
